PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name Robert Webster Widness
509 - 1445 Marpole Avenue,
Address Vancouver, B.C.
Birthplace Orillia, Onto

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1883 at Rocanville, 1887 at Moosomin.
Where did you set up housekeeping? ...........................................
Where had you been living before that? ..........Ontario.....................
For how many people did you prepare meals? An average of 7 or 8 at least.
How far was it to your nearest store?........Two blocks......................
How often could a visit be made to the store? Any time......................
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
All the staples.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? .....................
..........................................................................................................
In what quantities did you buy it? ........By the sack............................
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ..............
How much did you use graham flour? Quite a large percentage............
Whole wheat flour? ....Some, but not much........................................
Was flour milled locally?...Yes... How far away? ¼ mile. What year? 1888 or 9.
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ....................
What other grain products did you use? .....Wheat, oats and barley.....
Cornmeal? ...yes........ Whole Wheat?...yes..... Farina? Yes........
Other? ...Cracked wheat...............................................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ...No.............................
How did you grind it? .......................................................................
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1 "FOR THE YEARS 1887 TO 1900" ONLY

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Robert Widdess
Address: 506 1445 Harpole Avenue, Vancouver B.C.

Birthplace: Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1883 at Roseauville; 1887 at Mooseminn.

Where did you set up housekeeping? Outarix.

Where had you been living before that? An average of 7 or 8 at least.

For how many people did you prepare meals? Two blocks.

How far was it to your nearest store? Any time.

How often could a visit be made to the store? Any time.

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

ALL THE STAPLES.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?

In what quantities did you buy it? By the sack.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?

How much did you use graham flour? Quite a large percentage.

Whole wheat flour? Some, but not much.

Was flour milled locally? Yes. How far away? A mile. What year? 1888 or 9.

What was the price for a twenty pound bag or rolled oats?

What other grain products did you use? Wheat, oats, and barley.

Cornmeal? Yes. Whole Wheat? Yes. Cracked Wheat? Yes.

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.

How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...bulk...

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use?

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy?

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

We had our own cows.

Butter? Churned it ourselves.

Eggs? Had our own hens.

What was the price of butter? Of eggs?

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

How? In coarse salt

If I remember correctly, but it wasn't long before we had fresh eggs in the winter time too.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? From 1887 on, we had good butcher meat supplies in Moosomin.

How did you get fresh meat? At the butcher shop.

How often did you get fresh meat? Daily.

How did you preserve meat?

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood?

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes, quite a lot.

What kinds? Rabbits, Prairie chickens, Partridges, Ducks, Geese and occasionally Venison.

For how long? 1887 to 1905.

What part did fish play in the family diet? During this period whitefish began to come down by the sleigh load from the northern lakes.

We bought direct from the sleighs, and stacked them up in the wood shed for a time, but later the butchers stocked them for winter selling only. Early in this period butchers brought in bulk oysters from the Atlantic.

Salted and smoked herrings were carried by both butchers and stores, and canned salmon and sardines soon were available in the grocery stores.

Fresh fish were caught in the spring of the year, in the Pipestone chiefly so far as Moosomin was concerned. The consisted of pike, jack fish and suckers, but from Fish Lake in the Moose Mountains...
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ... [Blank]

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use?

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy?

At what prices?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

... [Blank]

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, I remember correctly, but it wasn't long before we had fresh eggs.

Did you make butter? Yes, in the winter time too.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? From 1867 on, we had good...

Butcher, meat, supplies, in Moosomin.

How did you get fresh meat? At the butcher shop.

How did you preserve meat?

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood?

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes, quite a lot.

What kind of game?

Prairie chickens, Partridges, ducks, Geese and occasionally Venison.

For how long? 1887 to 1905.

What part did fish play in the family diet? During this period, whitefish began to come down by the sleigh-load from the northern lakes.

We bought direct from the sleighs and stocked them in the store. But later, the stores were filled directly carried or canned.

Butchers stocked them for winter selling only. Rarely in this period.

Kinds? Also fish, butchers brought in bulk, oysters, from the Atlantic.

Salted and smoked herrings were carried by both butchers and stores.

Fresh fish were caught in the spring of the year, in the Lipestone stores.

Canned salmon and sardines soon were available in the grocery store.

Fresh fish so far as Moosomin was concerned. The consisted of pike, jack fish and suckers, but from Fish Lake in the Moose Mountains.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Green, black & Japan. What price? ...........

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Both. ............

Price? .................. What other beverages were used? Milk, Buttermilk, Berry juices, Lemonade.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? ..........

Could you get potatoes at the store? .......................

If not, where from? Every body grew their own. In our case from the seed stock my father brought with him from Ontario in 1883.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1884/5 Cabbage 1884/5 Carrots 1884/5 Onions 1884/5

Turnips 1884/5 Beets 1884/5

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? Bulk.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Bulk.

What weight? ........... How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes and also by the box.

What was the price of prunes? ..........................

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others) All these but loganberries.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.

Peas? Yes. Corn? Yes. Beans? Yes. Saskatoons? No.

Other foods? ..............................................

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? .................................

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? .................................

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? .................................

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? .................................

(I left the Province of Saskatchewan 1905.)

To what extent? ..............................................

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes, but not for long.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? (Green, black &. Jayne) what price?

What kind of coffee did you buy? (Beans or ground) …… Both …… Milk ……

What other beverages were used? ………… Butter milk, Berry juices, Lemonade.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?

Could you get potatoes at the store?

If not, where from? Every body grew their own. In our case, from the seed stock my father brought with him from Ontario in 1883.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1884/5 …… Carrots 1884/5 …… Onions 1884/5

Turnips 1884/5 …… Beets 1884/5

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? …… Bulk ……

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? …… Bulk ……

What weight? …… How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? …… Yes, and also by the box.

What was the price of prunes? …… What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others) All these but loganberries.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? …… Yes …… Peas? …… corn? …… Beans? …… Saskatoon? …… No …… other foods? …… Yes …… What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? …… What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? …… What year did you first preserve meat by canning? …… Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? …… (I left the province of Saskatchewan 1935.)

To what extent? …… Did you make your own vinegar? …… Yes, just not for long.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ........"Royal"........................

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes........ Using starter? ..........

Using hops? ......Yes.............. Salt rising? .....................

Did you buy baking powder? .................. Baking soda? ...............

Cream of tartar? ......................... Did you make your own baking powder?

.................................................................

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? "Royal"

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes

Using hops? Yes

Salt rising?

Did you buy baking powder?

Baking soda?

Cream of tartar?

Did you make your own baking powder?

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ................................................................. Well.

How far was this water from your home? ................................................... Couple of blocks away.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................................ Pail.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. No change at Moosomin 1887-1902. But, at Arcola where I worked 1903, water was brought down from the Moose Mountains in tanks and sold in the town for 25¢ per pail.

| FOOD | Earliest date it appeared on market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? (pail, barrel, tank) ..................................................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. No change at Moosomin 1897-1902. But, at Arcola where I worked 1903, water was brought down from the Moose Mountains in tanks and sold in the town for 25¢ per pail.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ... Both.

If you made your own, did you use lye? ... Yes. ... wood ashes? ... Yes.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? ... I think it was Royal Crown, not sure.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ... Wood at first, later both soft and hard coal.

Where did you get your fuel? ... Wood was sold by the wagon or sleigh load on the market square, in long poles, and had to be cut into stove lengths with buck saws, and then split.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Wood was mostly brought in by Jews from north of Red Jacket. Soft coal from the Souris mines along the southern boundary of Saskatchewan, was first brought in by wagon loads, but later by train around by Brandon. Fuel yards were started at an early date, possibly around 1888, and in addition to soft coals and wood, they carried small lots of hard coal from Pennsylvania. These yards usually carried lumber as well, and sometimes did a little trucking business on the side.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ... No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ... No.

By whom was your first cook stove made?

What year was it purchased? ... The same one we had on the farm, which we brought from Ontario in 1883.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ... A good supply was brought from Ontario.

For preparing feed? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ... A good supply came with us from Ontario 1883.

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum?
1887 - 1905

3. SOAPS
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Both.
If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes.
What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? I think it was Royal Crown, not sure.

4. FUEL
What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood at first, later both soft and hard coal.
Where did you get your fuel? Wood was sold by the wagon or sleigh load on the prairie, square in long lengths and had to be cut into store lengths with buck saws and then split.
Mention any changes in the use of fuel which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.
Wood was mostly brought in by Jews from north of Red Jacket.
Soft coal from the Souris mines along the southern boundary of Saskatchewan, was first brought in by wagon loads, but later by train around Brandon. Fuel yards were started at an early date, possibly around 1888, and in addition to soft coals and wood, they carried small lots of hard coal from Pennsylvania. These yards usually carried lumber as well, and sometimes did a little trucking business on the side.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)
No.
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)
No.
By whom was your first cook stove made?
What year was it purchased? The same one we had on the farm, which we brought from Ontario in 1883.
A good supply was brought from Ontario.
For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)
A good supply came with us from Ontario 1883.
When did you first see enamel ware?
Aluminum
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Fresh apples came in barrels.
Dried fruits, maple sugar and tea came in caddies.
Maple syrup in square sealed large cans.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? .......
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

We always had Christmas dinners at our place. On the farm it was in 1883,4,5,6. At Moosomin from 1887 and on.
Our own family consisted of:
Samuel Widness, Father,
Clarinda Widness, Mother,
Robert Webster Widness, Son,
Walter Wesley Widness,
William George Widness,
And we were never without guests for Christmas.
Another boy was born later. His name was Isaac Stanley Widness.
Victor Stanley Widness.

The writer Robert Webster Widness is now (1954) the sole survivor.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Fresh apples came in barrels. Bread fruits, maple sugar and tea came in caddies. Maple syrup in square sealed large cans.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at that time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

We always had Christmas dinners at our place. On the farm it was in 1889, 45, 6. At Moosomin from 1887 and on.

Our own family consisted of:
Samuel Widdess, Father
Clarinda Widdess, Mother
Robert Webster Widdess, Son
Walter Wesley Widdess, Son
William George Widdess, Son
And we were never without guests for Christmas.

Another boy was born later. His name was Isaac Widdess. Victor Stanley Widdess, the sole survivor.

19. Were the winder Robert Webster Widdess in flying on oils or into locally produced foods? Give details.

No.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Our meals have been wonderful at all times.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I left home on Jan 3, 1903, and from then on during the period 1887 to 1905, I lived in Hotels continuously.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).
Our meals have been wonderful at all times.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

I left home on Jan. 3, 1903, and from then on during the period 1887 to 1906, I lived in hotels continuously.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, problems of storage, shortage and other details. (One back of page if more space is needed.)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: ROBERT WEBSTER, MINNESTONKA
Address: 509 Hycroft Towers, Vancouver 9, B.C.
Birthplace: ONTARIO

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1883 (of course)
Where did you set up housekeeping? R.W.A. Sec.28, Tn.17, Rge.31, West 1st P.M.
Where had you been living before that? ORILLIA, ONTARIO
For how many people did you prepare meals?
How far was it to your nearest store? 30 miles to Fort Riley or 25 miles to Moosomin.
How often could a visit be made to the store? 2 or 3 times a year.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
In what quantities did you buy it?
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes, Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other? Cracked wheat, Oatmeal.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.
How did you grind it?
1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? (1883, 1884, etc., or course)

Where did you set up housekeeping? (e.g., Saskatoon, Regina, etc.)

Where had you been living before that? (e.g., Ontario, Quebec, etc.)

How far was it to your nearest store? (e.g., 20 miles, 50 miles, etc.)

How often could a visit be made to the store? (e.g., once a month, twice a month, etc.)

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?

In what quantities did you buy it?

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?

How much did you use graham flour?

Whole wheat flour?

Was flour milled locally? How far away? That year?

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?

What other grain products did you use?

Oatmeal? Yeast? Whole Wheat? Farina?

Other? (e.g., cracked wheat, oatmeal)

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.

How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...........................................

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ...........................................

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...........................................

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...........................................

(During the years 1883-1887 I do not recall my parents having had any white sugar, but we had plenty of maple sugar and syrup sent out to us from relatives in Ontario. We also had supplies of a brown granulated coarse sugar, but it was not popular. Maple sugar and syrup were brought along in our settlers' car, but not enough to last five years)

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ...........................................

We had our own cows, brought out from Ontario.

Butter? Churned right on the farm.

Eggs? We had lots of hens.

What was the price of butter? ........................................... or eggs? ...........................................

Did you pack eggs for winter? ... No. ........................................... how? ...........................................

Did you make butter? ... Yes. ........................................... cheese? ... No. ...........................................

What kind of cheese? ...........................................

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ... Mostly game. ...........................................

Occasionally, occasionally my father killed a steer, hog or sheep, but that was usually in the winter time. The farm was also well stocked with all varieties of barnyard fowl.

How did you get fresh meat? ...........................................

How often did you get fresh meat? ...........................................

How did you preserve meat? ... We froze it in the winter and divided it among the neighbors during warmer weather.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ... No, I don't think you could call it by that name.

If so what year was it organized? ...........................................

Did you use game? ... Yes. ........................................... What kinds? Venison, Rabbits, Hares, Prairie chickens, Partridges, Ducks and Geese.

For how long? ... 1883 to 1887.

What part did fish play in the family diet? ... Quite an important part.

Chiefly in the Spring of the year.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ... Fresh.

Kinds? Jack fish, Pike and Suckers.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar?
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?
What brand of refined corn syrup did you use?
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy?
At what price? Having had to buy molasses sugar, but not had any for sale.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

Sugar and syrup seem our only supplies of sugar and syrup were brought along by our settlers or but not enough to last five years.

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

butter? Cheese? Eggs? Butter? Cheese? Eggs?

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes. No.

Did you make butter? Yes. No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

That was your most important in the early years? Mostly. Usually. Occasionally.

Occasionally my father killed a steer, hog, or beef, but that was usually in the winter time. The farm was also well stocked with all varieties of perennial fowl.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? We froze it in the winter, and dried it among the neighbors during warmer weather.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? If so, what year was it organized?

Did you have game? Yes. No.

For how long? From 1883 to 1887.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Quite an important part.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds: Trout, Pike, and Suckers.
Mr James Carscadden told me in 1953 that he is still growing potatoes at Wapella, from the seed stock my father gave him presumably from the same seed potatoes he brought from Ontario in 1883.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Fresh apples came in barrels.
Dried apples, maple sugar and tea came in caddies.
Maple syrup in square cans.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1881.
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Six uncles and aunts ranging from twenty to forty-five years.
Nine children from babies to twelve or thirteen years.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Fresh apples came in barrels. In minute tins, sugar and tea came in canisters.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the number of the family members present at the time. State the approximate weather or season.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Six uncles and aunts ranging from twenty to forty-five years.

Nine children from babies to twelve or thirteen years.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two loaves of bread?

At least two or three times.
